properties.PlanRegion: NEWARK BAY, HACKENSACK & PASSAIC RIVERS STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: Richard P. Kane Natural Area is bordered on the east by the Hackensack River and on the south by the New Jersey Turnpike-Western Spur, in Carlstadt, NJ.
properties.Flora: Richard P. Kane Natural Area is dominated by common reed (Phragmites australis).
properties.UseDescrip: Richard P. Kane Natural Area is currently used as brackish marsh and freshwater marsh.
properties.History: Site history is included in various sources, including a 2002 EIS, for Richard P. Kane Natural Area.
properties.Culture: Baseline data has been collected for Richard P. Kane Natural Area for the 2002 EIS.

properties.Flora: Estuarine - marshes, tidal waterway, estuarine embayment, shellfish reefs. Currently the vegetation consists of mostly invasive species.

properties.LocationDescrip: .5 miles south from the corner of Arthur Kill Road and Woodrow Road
properties.OtherDescrip: A pond has been formed by the impoundment of water by two structures, which are the impediments, and a small hill. On one side of the hill, there is a small rock overflow.  On the other side, a wooden dam limits drainage of the small upstream pond.
properties.Notes: This site is retired - all complete

properties.LocationDescrip: An island in central Jamaica Bay, .25 miles west of Cross Bay Boulevard, Kings County, NY.  Yellow Bar is located about 1.5 miles south-southeast of Elders Point.  The islands are separated from each other by Pumpkin Patch, Duck Point, and Stony Creek mar
properties.Flora: The project sites are comprised of intertidal salt marsh and mudflats. Low marsh vegetated by smooth cordgrass (Spartina alterniflora) is the dominant wetland type. With exception for small portions, the island is almost completely inundated twice daily d
properties.UseDescrip: Yellow Bar Hassock Marsh is part of GNRA. The land is zoned an open/recreational site with federal land.
properties.History: The only documented activity (habitation, commercials, industrial) on these islands is several historic fishing shacks on the south side of Yellow Bar. Historcally the island was 235 acres in size.
properties.OtherDescrip: Limited surveys of Yellow Bar Hassock Marsh indicate a low range in variability across the idland, with elevations of the vegetated and unvegetated areas primarily ranging from 0 ft to +2.4 ft NAVD. There is a large overlap in the vegetative communities,

properties.PlanRegion: HARLEM RIVER, EAST RIVER, & WESTERN LONG ISLAND SOUND STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: 0.1 miles north northwest from the Intersection of East Broadway and Paper Mill Road, Roslyn, NY.
properties.SiteAcquisitionStatus: The site is within New York State-regulated waters; land acquisition not required for restoration.
properties.SiteRestorationStatus:
Restoration Complete
Nassau County seeded 2-million shellfish and monitored survival of the seedlings to repopulate Hempstead Harbor with this historically abundant fishery. While seedling survivorship was very low, the water quality improvement enabled NYSDEC to reopen the harbor to shellfishing.
properties.CoastWetNote: Create low tidal marsh habitat, filtration marsh and possible catch basin for storm water outfall at the mill which is impacting existing marsh habitat at the south end of the harbor. Remove riprap and regrade shoreline to create a low tidal marsh on the
properties.ForestsNote: Restoration/preservation of ~83.7 acres of forested shrub buffer. Assessment for invasives with potential to expand the area through plantings.
properties.AquaticHabNote: Addition of complex structure and enhancements to the mudflats along ~105.82 acres surrounding the wetlands.
properties.OysterNote: Support ongoing efforts to re-introduce shellfish populations to Hempstead Harbor.
properties.WaterNote: Restore natural bathymetry along ~10,944 feet of the harbor to reduce the tidal prism and increase harbor flushing rate.
properties.TributaryNote: Assessment of culverts and storm water outfalls for capacity to connect ~2,150 feet of creek.
properties.SedimentNote: Potential dredging and capping of contaminated sediment based on testing.
properties.HabOther: NYS Department of State 'Significant Coastal Fish & Wildlife Habitat'
properties.Fauna: Abundant waterfowl population and productivity as a marine finfish nursery and feeding habitat. Various shorebirds also utilize the site during migratory periods and wading birds during the summer months.
properties.History: Beginning in 2004, Nassau County, the Coalition to Save Hempstead Harbor, and NYSDEC conducted water quality sampling surveys to determine if the upper bay could be reopened for shellfish harvesting. The project team then seeded the Harbor with 1.3 million oysters and clams in 2007, undertaking surveys throughout 2008 to assess seed survival. The study results conclude poor seed survival, likely due to lack of sufficient habitat and predation. However, the positive water quality results allowed NYSDEC to open Hempstead Harbor to shellfishing.
properties.OtherDescrip:
Hempstead Harbor is characterized by a tidal range of approximately 7 – 8 feet and is designated by NYS Department of State as a Significant Coastal Fish & Wildlife Habitat. 

Historically, Hempstead Harbor supported thriving salt marshes which have deter
properties.GWater: Village of Sea Cliff Hempstead Harbor Water Quality Monitoring Program.

properties.PlanRegion: NEWARK BAY, HACKENSACK & PASSAIC RIVERS STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: Secaucus High School bordered on the north by the Hackensack River and the southeast by Mill Ridge Road in Secaucus, NJ.
properties.Flora: The Secuacus High School site was formerly dominated by Phragmites. Restoration performed by NJMC in 2007 included the eradication of phragmites and placement of 'engineered' soil to create high marsh.
properties.UseDescrip: Secaucus High School is currently used as a tidal marsh.
properties.History: No data has been obtained for Secaucus High School.
properties.Culture: No data has been obtained for Secaucus High School.
properties.Notes: Terry says retire this one - restored

properties.PlanRegion: ARTHUR KILL/KILL VAN KULL STUDY AREA
properties.OtherDescrip: Acquisition of 4 acres of woodlands and wetlands at Clark Reservoir in Clark Township (Union County, New Jersey) with funds from Union County Department of Parks.

properties.PlanRegion: HARLEM RIVER, EAST RIVER, & WESTERN LONG ISLAND SOUND STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: The site is along Bronxville Lake on the Bronx River in the Village of Bronxville.
properties.Ownership: Westchester County Department of Parks, Recreation, and Conservation
properties.AquaticHabNote: Fish passage installation for increased connectivity and habitat.
properties.TributaryNote: Increased channel connectivity. Channel realignment with in stream structures.
properties.Flora: Isolated trees and small woody species.
properties.OtherDescrip:
Lawn and eroding stream banks used to characterize the shoreline of Bronxville Lake.  Geese had trampled streamside vegetation, leaving behind bare, highly erodible soil next to the lake, which is formed by a dam on the Bronx River.  

Baseline Conditions

properties.PlanRegion: NEWARK BAY, HACKENSACK & PASSAIC RIVERS STUDY AREA
properties.LocationDescrip: Located along the west ascending bank of the Passaic River at river mile 5.9 in the City of Newark.
properties.Ownership: Norfolk Southern Corp., Colonial Concrete, Valenta Nichilis
properties.CoastWetNote: Enhance the existing habitat along the newly re-graded shoreline by increasing the density of native vegetation and removing invasives to create ≈0.60 acres of fringe marsh habitat.
properties.AquaticHabNote: Assessment of ≈0.20 acres of flats for composition, level of degradation and potential enhancements such as addition of complex structure to the small shoreline and mudflats section just north of the Interstate 280 bridge to facilitate connections between
properties.ShoreNote: Remove fill and re-grade shorelines to wetland elevations.  Remove rip rap and bulkhead to allow subtidal sedimentation in an area where bulkheads have cause erosion.  Re-structure shoreline with stable slope and rocky structure to restore ≈369.83 linear
properties.SedimentNote: Potential dredging and capping of contaminated materials based on sediment sampling.
properties.UseDescrip: This site is currently forested open space.  NJDEP has zoned this site as urban.
properties.OtherDescrip: This site contains forested fringe habitat along the Passaic River.  The site boarders an industrial facility, Interstate 280 and the Colonial Concrete facility.  The extent of bulkhead and riprap at this site is unknown; however, there is some softened s
properties.ASurvey: USGS digital raster graphic maps and NJDEP Regional Data inclusive of this site.
properties.BHistory: No data obtained on history. Vacant forested lot adjacent to active industrial sites.
properties.DEnvironment: Benthic community composition and fish/crab tissue chemistry and pathology, Passaic River Study Area Investigations (9, 10).
properties.EGeotechnical: Sediment characterization in 1995, 1996 and 2005 by Aqua Survey Inc. (3). No data above high tide.
properties.GWater: Newark Bay Estuary Sediment Characterization 1990-1993 (4), limited surface water quality and sediment data from Passaic River Study Area Investigations (5,6). Water Quality NJHDG 2002-present (7).

properties.Address: St Francis Friary, Todt Hill Road, Staten Island, NY
properties.LocationDescrip: The southern main driveway for the Friary, to be used as a main public access point.
properties.SiteRestorationStatus:
This acquisition would allow for direct public access to the St. Francis woodland site already held by NYSDEC. The
woodland on the edge of the driveway would be restored to improve the understory and tree species diversity. Obtaining this driveway would p
properties.AccessNote:
This acquisition would allow for direct public access to the St. Francis woodland site already held by NYSDEC. The
woodland on the edge of the driveway would be restored to improve the understory and tree species diversity.
properties.Flora: Trees on the edge of the driveway are exclusively Norway maple.
properties.Fauna: Squirrels, songbirds, raccoons, the normal suite of suburban wildlife.
properties.UseDescrip: currently used for storage of trucks, equipment and wood debris
properties.Notes: This site should be retired - restoration/acquisition complete
